title: Meeting with Don Ramon de Perellós on Council Administration

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk through the Barri Gòtic is pleasant despite the weight of the morning's conversations. Lucia walks beside you, her hand resting lightly on your arm. She says little, but her presence is steady. The Palau Reial rises at the heart of the old city—less imposing than Toledo's Alcázar, but older, its stones worn smooth by centuries of Catalan counts and Aragonese kings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon de Perellós receives you in the regent's council chamber—a long room dominated by a heavy oak table and tapestries depicting the conquest of Majorca. He rises from behind a desk cluttered with documents, bowing precisely.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Majesty. I trust the morning has been productive. I have prepared a proposed itinerary for Your Majesty's remaining time in Barcelona. The Consell de Cent at midday, as arranged. The Count of Pallars has requested a private audience—I have suggested the fourth hour after noon, if that suits. Don Guillem de Vic wishes to present certain communications he has drafted on Your Majesty's behalf. I understand Your Majesty visited Bishop Climent Sapera this morning. A lengthy meeting, by all accounts.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for the effort and care you took for facilitating these meetings. I trust there are issues or matters you yourself want to discuss with us as well? We are here and you have our ear.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. The matter of the itinerary is not... merely logistical. Barcelona is not Toledo, Your Majesty. The Consell de Cent guards its prerogatives jealously. The Count of Pallars speaks for nobles who remember when Aragón's king lived in Aragón. The merchants want to know whether Castilian trade agreements will respect Catalan privileges. In four years as head of the regency council, I have learned that scheduling is governance. Who sees the king, and when, and in what order—these things matter. They send signals. They create expectations. They establish... hierarchies. Your Majesty arrived yesterday evening. Since then, you have spoken privately with Don Guillem de Vic, with the Count of Pallars, and this morning—at considerable length—with Bishop Climent Sapera. The regency council was not consulted regarding any of these conversations. Queen María has requested that I coordinate all further meetings through Her Majesty's secretary. She wishes to be informed in advance of Your Majesty's appointments.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And I appologize immediately for not consulting with you sooner. An oversight I cannot take back. You have my word that not seeing you sooner was somehow a deliberate act to undermine your authority or to diminish it. I simply took audiences with anyone willing to speak with me. But now that we are here, what matters should we discuss? And what are the concerns of the regency council?

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's word is noted. Your Majesty asks what the council's concerns are. That is a... complex question. The council's concerns depend greatly on circumstances. On what is being proposed. On what commitments may already have been made. I have served as head of this council for four years. In that time, I have learned that I cannot advise a king on what he should do until I understand what he has done. Don Guillem de Vic left the reception last night speaking of 'great things to come' and 'bringing the kingdoms together.' The Count of Pallars sent a messenger to his estates at first light—I do not know why. Bishop Climent Sapera has reportedly cancelled his morning appointments to draft letters to the Archbishop of Tarragona. What should the regency council's concerns be, Your Majesty? What has been discussed? What has been offered? What expectations now exist that did not exist two days ago?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan tells the regent exactly what has happened and does not hold back. He tells him about his vision for a better world and how bringing the kingdoms closer together might help this. That he has been able to share this vision with others who are now also trying to achieve this. That the kingdoms uniting should not be Aragon joining Castille, but both kingdoms joining to become something else with neither holding dominance. He also tells him that he talked about the crown succession with Maria. And that he should have asked her about the current situation regarding succession and his own role in this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon listens without interruption. His face remains carefully composed throughout—the practiced stillness of a man who has spent decades hearing kings and nobles speak of grand designs. When Juan finishes, Don Ramon is silent for a long moment. He moves to the window again, looking out at the courtyard below where servants cross on their errands.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has been... remarkably candid. You ask about the succession. That, at least, is a matter of law rather than vision. King Alfonso has no legitimate children. Queen María has borne none, and the physicians hold little hope after so many years. Should Alfonso die, the Crown of Aragón passes to his nearest male relative. The Infantes Juan and Enrique are dead. Their legitimate male issue—Carlos of Viana—is also dead. This leaves... King Ferdinand of Aragón, Alfonso's father, had one other son who survived infancy. That son married into the House of Trastámara. His daughter María is our regent. His son... His son is Your Majesty. By strict succession law, should Alfonso die without heir, the Crown of Aragón would pass to the descendants of Ferdinand's second son—that is, to Juan II of Castile. Your Majesty is, in fact, Alfonso's heir presumptive. The regency council is aware of this. The factions are aware of this. When Your Majesty speaks of 'bringing kingdoms together,' every man in Barcelona hears it through this lens. I would suggest that further discussions regarding succession—or visions of unity—include Her Majesty the Regent and the full council. These are not matters for private conversations with faction leaders and bishops. Is there anything else Your Majesty requires for the midday reception with the Consell de Cent?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You indicate that further discussions about unity should include the full council. Since everybody seems to be thinking about this already, can such a meeting be arranged?

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Don Ramon de Perellós, head of the regency council, who questions his private meetings with various factions. Juan makes full disclosure of his unity vision and succession concerns. Don Ramon reveals that Juan is legally Alfonso's heir presumptive to Aragón, explaining why his talk of 'bringing kingdoms together' alarms everyone. He insists future discussions involve the full council.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: The regency council is aware of this. The factions are aware of this. When Your Majesty speaks of 'bringing kingdoms together,' every man in Barcelona hears it through this lens.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves back toward the desk, straightening papers that do not need straightening.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: I would suggest that further discussions regarding succession—or visions of unity—include Her Majesty the Regent and the full council. These are not matters for private conversations with faction leaders and bishops.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: Is there anything else Your Majesty requires for the midday reception with the Consell de Cent?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Since everybody seems to be thinking about this already, can such a meeting be arranged?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon's expression flickers—something that might be satisfaction, quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: A meeting can always be arranged, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves to the desk, pulling a ledger toward him and opening it with the practiced ease of a man who lives by schedules.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: The question is when, and with what preparation. The Consell de Cent expects you at midday. The Count of Pallars has the afternoon. Don Guillem wishes to present his drafted communications. Your Majesty departs for Rome within... how many days?

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: A full council meeting requires the presence of all principal members. Don Berenguer de Bardaxí is at his estates—two days' ride. The Bishop of Girona sits on the council; he is in Girona. The Viscount of Rocabertí... These men cannot be summoned like servants. They must be invited, given time to arrange their affairs, travel to Barcelona.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He closes the ledger.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: And Her Majesty the Regent must, of course, preside. Given Your Majesty's conversation with her this morning, I would suggest... I would suggest that Her Majesty's consent to such a meeting should be obtained before invitations are dispatched.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perrellos
exchanges.text: Shall I inquire of Her Majesty whether she finds such a meeting advisable, and if so, when it might be convened? I could have an answer for Your Majesty by this evening. After the Count of Pallars, perhaps.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Don Ramon, I have 4-5 weeks before I have to leave for Rome. I realize that I cannot summon the council. You have told me that everyone is thinking about succession right now. And you have indicated that talk about succession should happen through the council. Would it please the council to discuss these matters? To create stability and clarity perhaps? I will refrain from succession talk and refer to the council should the subject come up. Would this be in accordance with your wishes?

encounters.recap: Juan requests a full regency council meeting to address succession matters that are already on everyone's minds. Don Ramón carefully explains the logistical requirements and political protocols needed for such a meeting, emphasizing that Queen María must consent and preside. Juan agrees to defer all succession discussions to the council's authority.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Saló de Cent—the Hall of the Hundred—occupies the heart of the Casa de la Ciutat, a stern stone building that speaks of civic pride and commercial power. Inside, the hall is smaller than Toledo's throne room but no less impressive in its way. Pointed arches rise to a wooden ceiling painted in red and gold. The walls bear the arms of Barcelona—the red and gold bars of Aragón quartered with the cross of Sant Jordi. Wooden benches line the chamber in rising tiers, and upon them sit the jurats: one hundred men in dark robes and furred caps, the elected governors of one of the Mediterranean's greatest trading cities.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesties of Castile. Barcelona welcomes you. I am Pere Joan de Sant Climent, conseller en cap. We are honored by your presence in our city. We understand Your Majesty has recently achieved a great victory against the Moor. The Consell wishes to offer its congratulations. Granada's fall is a triumph for all Christendom. We also understand that Granada's ports now fly Castilian banners. Málaga. Almería. Ports that once competed with Barcelona for the African trade. Perhaps Your Majesty would honor us by sharing how Castile intends to... organize these new commercial opportunities?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for granting us audience and to introduce us to this chamber and this intricate system of governance. I am here with my queen to meet with my sister and to learn about Catalan customs. You ask specifically about how to exploit the trade in Grenada. I must confess that I have not yet made any major decisions. Maybe I should summon all the traders in the region in one council and come up with a system or structure for trade. But I can already tell you what my aim is going to be; I want trade to increase and cooperation as well. There are many fields where Aragonese and Castillian interests align. Already I am moving against Muslim piracy that has plagued our coasts for so long. Areas where Castille can indeed draw upon the expertise of friends like Aragon, should they choose to give it.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty mentions summoning traders to create a system. A worthy thought. Might we ask—which traders? Castilian traders from Seville, who already control the Atlantic routes? Or will Catalan houses receive equal voice in this... council? Your Majesty speaks of cooperation. Of aligned interests. We hear these words and we are grateful for them. But Your Majesty will forgive us—we are merchants. We think in contracts, not sentiments. When Málaga's harbor opens to Christian trade, will a Catalan ship pay the same duties as a Castilian ship? Will Barcelona's cloth merchants have the same rights in Granada's markets as Burgos wool factors? These are not challenges, Your Majesty. Merely... the questions that keep merchants awake at night.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe I should take a step back and let you explain what you are really concerned about. And what a king such as I could do to address them. I do not set or control prices of trade goods. If Grenada weavers choose to now enter the Christian market, they are free to do so. My question to you would be: Is this not free commerce? Please tell me what a king of a kingdom not even your own gathers so much interest from this council.

exchanges.speaker: pere_joan_de_sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks a fair question. You are correct. You are King of Castile. Aragonese trade policy is a matter for King Alfonso and the regency council. We overstep. And yet. Your Majesty will forgive us if we speak plainly. We are Catalans. Plainness is our vice. King Alfonso pursues his destiny in Naples. Queen María holds Aragón in trust. And the man who stands before us today is... a man of great consequence. A man who has achieved what no Christian king has achieved in two centuries. A man whose shadow falls long across all of Iberia.

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks what a Castilian king could do to address our concerns. The answer is simple: nothing. Today. But we are merchants. We plan for tomorrow. We sign contracts that bind our grandchildren. We think in generations. Every man in this chamber knows the succession laws of Aragón. Every man knows that King Alfonso has no heir. Every man knows who stands next in line. We do not ask Your Majesty to make promises you cannot keep. We ask only... to understand what kind of king you are. Whether you see Barcelona as a partner or as a... subject.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! I consider plainness no vice at all. And even if it is a sin, I am a likewise a sinner like you. You ask me what kind of king I am. That I can do. Though I risk a bit of pride about my accomplishments, but I have taken my queen with me, who is sure to let me know when I do. When developing trade policy, I ask myself one question. What will increase trade the most? What develops ports? How can trade goods reach workshops? In short; how will this benefit the kingdom the most. And I must confess that trade and naval matters are not areas of Castillian strengths. My kingdom barely has a fleet compared to Aragon. A matter I intend to address and I have moored my full fleet in Valencia, putting it at the disposal of your king in support of his Naples campaign. I honestly do not know what trade policies to adopt. I have never done so yet. But I have already said what I want these policies to achieve. Should anything change, I can assure this council that I will always seek out advice from bodies such as these and that I aim for policies that increase trade. Does this address your question?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says you will seek advice from bodies such as ours. We are grateful. But seeking advice and heeding advice are different things. Castile has a Cortes. Aragón has Corts. Both give advice. Kings do not always listen. You say you want policies that increase trade. So do we. But whose trade? When a Castilian merchant and a Catalan merchant both want the same contract in Málaga, whose trade increases? This is not philosophy, Your Majesty. This is Tuesday.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, I can be specific in case of the example of the Catalan merchant and the Castillian merchant competing for the same contract on a tuesday. In the current situation, what would happen? Is the Castillian merchant in an advantage because he is trading in what essentially is Castillian territory?

exchanges.speaker: bernat_fiveller
exchanges.text: An excellent question, Your Majesty. At present, Granada's ports are... chaos. Forgive my bluntness. Málaga fell less than two years ago. Almería even more recently. The old Moorish trading houses are disrupted. The new Christian administration is still finding its feet. In such chaos, advantage flows to those with connections. Castilian merchants from Seville know your port officials. They speak the same language. They worship in the same churches. They have cousins and brothers-in-law in the customs houses. A Catalan merchant arrives in Málaga and he is... a foreigner. Tolerated, yes. But a foreigner. So when we ask whether Catalan ships will be welcomed as friends—we ask whether Your Majesty will instruct your officials that Catalans are not foreigners. That we are... partners. With the same rights, the same access, the same three days for a license. That is not a trade policy. That is a letter. A few sentences. 'Treat Aragonese merchants as you would Castilian merchants.' Nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have already told you what my policy should aim to accomplish. And treating Catalan merchants the same as Castillian ones would fit that narrative.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Barcelona's Consell de Cent to discuss trade relations. The councillors, led by Pere Joan de Sant Climent and merchant representative Bernat Fiveller, press him about preferential treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's newly conquered ports. They acknowledge Juan's likely future as King of Aragón and seek concrete assurances about equal treatment. Juan offers philosophical support for fair trade but avoids specific commitments, ultimately agreeing that equal treatment would align with his stated goals.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: There is no law against Catalan trade in Granada's ports. But law and practice are different things. A Castilian factor obtains a license in three days. A Catalan factor waits three weeks. A Castilian ship unloads at the prime berths. A Catalan ship anchors in the outer harbor.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: These are not conspiracies, Your Majesty. They are... human nature. Your officials favor their own. As ours would. So when we ask whether Catalan ships will be welcomed as friends—we ask whether Your Majesty will instruct your officials that Catalans are not foreigners. That we are... partners. With the same rights, the same access, the same three days for a license. That is not a trade policy. That is a letter. A few sentences. 'Treat Aragonese merchants as you would Castilian merchants.' Nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have already told you what my policy should aim to accomplish. And treating Catalan merchants the same as Castillian ones would fit that narrative. If you want for me to draft official trade policy right here and right now, I must disappoint you. Imagine your king Alfonso drafting Aragonese trade policy while talking with Castillian traders in Castille! No, that would be unfair to those not represented. Do traders from Aragon and Castille meet somewhere? Maybe we should invite Portugal as well. Does such a structure yet exist? And if not, should we try and set up such a meeting?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ripple passes through the hall. Men exchange glances—some intrigued, others skeptical. Fiveller's expression tightens almost imperceptibly.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: An international meeting of traders. A noble thought, Your Majesty. Truly. Such meetings have been proposed before. At Bruges. At Genoa. They take years to arrange. They produce... documents. Declarations of intent. Frameworks for future cooperation. Meanwhile, my ships sail to Málaga next month. Not next year. Next month.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: Senyor Fiveller speaks from... urgency. Which is understandable. But Your Majesty raises an interesting question. Such a structure does not exist—not formally. The crowns negotiate. The merchants... adapt. Barcelona would be honored to host such a gathering, should one be arranged. It would be... good for the city. But this is a matter of years, not weeks.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I asked for a letter. A few sentences instructing your port officials to treat our merchants as equals. Not a policy. Not a treaty. A letter. Is that truly something that requires an international conference to decide?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Done. Can I have ink and quill? Lucia, would you be so kind as to draft this letter? Are there other issues we should include in the letter? Cooperation about piracy maybe? Or other matters?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall stirs. Whatever the merchants expected, it was not this. Fiveller stands frozen for a moment—a man who asked for a fish and has been handed the net. Sant Climent gestures to a clerk, who scurries forward with writing materials. A small table is brought, set before Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty is inclined to address matters of mutual concern... the piracy question is indeed pressing. A statement of intent—that Castile and Aragón will cooperate against the Salé corsairs—would be most welcome.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: And perhaps... clarification on customs rates? If Catalan merchants are to be treated as equals, does this extend to the duties they pay? Equal access means little if we are taxed more heavily.

exchanges.speaker: artisan_representative
exchanges.text: The silk, Majestic. You spoke of increasing trade. But trade in what? If Granada's silk floods our markets without restriction... Can the letter say something about... balance? That Your Majesty will not permit Granada's looms to destroy Valencia's? Some protection for those who weave, not only those who trade?

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: And information, Your Majesty. When Castile makes decisions that affect our merchants, will Barcelona be informed? Consulted? Or will we learn of new policies when our ships are turned away?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before we start, I want to make sure that you all understand that I write this letter as king of Castille, aiming to increase cooperation and good standing between my kingdom and Aragon. Lets start with the pirates. The military orders have been ordered to construct a navy to fight pirates. Order them to focus their efforts on Sale. Coordinate with Aragon should they support this effort. We await what they should choose to commit. Harbour officials should know that Aragonese, Portugese and Castillian merchants should be treated equally and are subject to the same treatment and tax. Regarding the silk trade from Grenada, inform the duke of Grenada to develop policies to prevent Grenada silk to flood and disrupt the christian markets as we integrate Grenada into Castille. We adopt a policy where Portugese and Aragonese traders are informed about our taxes and any significant changes to them so traders can make better informed decisions. And finally, If Barcelona would be so kind as to host a meeting of traders of these kingdoms so we can further develop and discuss these issues, I would encourage the Castillian traders to attend, send a delegation and to work in good spirit towards a common purpose where trade flourishes. Does the council have anything else to add?

exchanges.speaker: artisan_representative
exchanges.text: Your Majesty says the Governor of Granada should 'develop policies to prevent disruption.' Forgive me, Majestic—but what policies? Tariffs on Moorish silk entering Christian markets? Quotas on how much can be sold? Policies can mean many things. My weavers need to know if they will have work next year.

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: Your Majesty offers to inform us of tax changes. We are grateful. But I asked whether Barcelona might be consulted. These are... different things. To be informed is to learn what has been decided. To be consulted is to speak before the decision is made.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: And the equal treatment—this is most welcome. But does 'subject to the same tax' mean Catalan merchants pay what Castilians pay now? Or might all rates rise together, equally but... higher? We do not doubt Your Majesty's intentions. Only... words on parchment have a way of meaning different things to different readers.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am willing to accomodate this council in the spirit of cooperation. But cooperation goes both ways. Is this council ready to commit to consult Castillian traders on future trade policy of Aragon? I am not asking for it, but my traders would ask me right now to ask reciprocity in regards to a commitment to the same taxes and treatment of Castillian traders in Aragonese harbours. Before you ask for something, consider what it would look like if the shoe were on the other foot. I am taking very concrete steps to adress your concerns right now and I must leave my officials enough flexibility to effectively implement them. So I ask again, what issues would this council like to include as well?

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: Your Majesty raises a... fair point. We have perhaps spoken as though this chamber sets policy for the Crown of Aragón. It does not. We govern Barcelona. We advise Her Majesty the Regent. But trade policy for the realm... That is a matter for the regency council. We cannot commit King Alfonso to reciprocal treatment of Castilian merchants in Aragonese ports. That is not our authority.

exchanges.speaker: citizens_representative
exchanges.text: What we can commit, Your Majesty, is Barcelona. This city. This port. If Your Majesty instructs Málaga and Almería to treat Catalans as equals, this council can instruct Barcelona's harbor officials to extend the same courtesy to Castilians. Equal berthing. Equal licensing times. Equal treatment in the customs house.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: That much is within our power. And we would be... willing to put it in writing. A matching commitment. Barcelona's word alongside Castile's.

exchanges.speaker: fiveller
exchanges.text: And the trading conference. If Barcelona hosts such a meeting, we commit our resources. Our halls. Our hospitality. That is something concrete we can offer.

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: Is this acceptable, Your Majesty? Barcelona's commitment, in writing, to match your own terms—equal treatment, equal access—for Castilian merchants in our port? And our pledge to host and support the international gathering you propose?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That sounds fair. Is the letter finished Lucia? If it is, would you be so kind as to read it aloud for this council?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia sets down the quill and lifts the parchment, allowing the ink a moment to dry. She rises from the small table, her bearing regal despite the improvised setting. The hall falls utterly silent.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, to all officials, harbor masters, and servants of the Crown within Our realm, and to all Christian princes and merchants who may read these words, greeting. In the spirit of cooperation between Christian kingdoms and for the increase of honest trade, We do hereby decree and instruct as follows: First, that the Masters of the Orders of Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara shall direct their nascent naval forces toward the suppression of piracy, with particular attention to the corsairs of Salé who prey upon Christian shipping. They shall coordinate such efforts with the Kingdom of Aragón, should that realm choose to commit forces to this righteous cause. Second, that all harbor officials within Our realm, and most especially those of Málaga, Almería, and such other ports as fall under Our authority, shall treat merchants of Aragón and Portugal as they would treat merchants of Castile—subject to the same customs, the same duties, the same courtesies, and the same speed of licensing, with no distinction made upon the origin of their vessels. Third, that Don García López de Padilla, Governor of Granada, shall develop such policies as prevent the silk trade of that newly Christian territory from flooding and disrupting the markets of our brother kingdoms, so that the integration of Granada into Christendom proceeds with balance and justice to all. Fourth, that Our officials shall adopt a practice of informing the merchants of Portugal and Aragón of significant changes to customs rates and trading regulations, so that honest traders may make informed decisions. Fifth, that We encourage the city of Barcelona, should it choose to host a gathering of traders from the Christian kingdoms of Iberia, and We shall encourage Castilian merchants to attend such a meeting in good faith, sending proper delegation to work toward the common flourishing of trade. Given under Our hand, in the city of Barcelona, in the year of Our Lord fourteen hundred and thirty-four. Juan Rex

exchanges.speaker: sant_climent
exchanges.text: This is... more than we expected, Your Majesty. Barcelona will honor its commitment. Equal treatment for Castilian merchants in our port. In writing, as promised. Does the Consell de Cent consent to Barcelona's reciprocal commitment?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur rises—and then, starting from the merchants' benches and spreading through the artisans and citizens, a growing chorus: 'Sí. Sí. Sí.'

encounters.recap: Juan II concludes trade negotiations with Barcelona's Consell de Cent by drafting a comprehensive royal letter addressing Catalan concerns about equal treatment in Castilian ports, anti-piracy cooperation, Granada silk regulation, and information sharing. The council reciprocates by committing Barcelona to equal treatment of Castilian merchants and agreeing to host an international traders' conference.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Ramon returns precisely as the cathedral bells mark the hour. He escorts Juan and Lucia through the Palau Reial to a smaller receiving chamber—intimate, private, away from listening ears. "The Count awaits within. I informed Her Majesty of the Consell de Cent's... outcome." He pauses. "She expressed surprise." He does not elaborate on what kind of surprise. The door opens. Hug Roger III, Count of Pallars Sobirà, rises from a chair by the window. He is perhaps fifty, grey-bearded, with the weathered face of a man who has spent decades managing mountain territories on the French border. His clothing is fine but not ostentatious—practicality over display. His bow is correct, nothing more.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. Thank you for receiving me privately. What I have to say is... not for general ears.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course count. Let us go inside and listen to what you have to say.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is small, wood-paneled, lit by narrow windows overlooking an interior courtyard. Don Ramon withdraws, closing the door behind him with a soft click. Pallars does not sit until Juan and Lucia have taken their seats. When he does, he leans forward, elbows on knees, hands clasped—a soldier's posture, not a courtier's.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: I will not waste Your Majesty's time with pleasantries. Last night you showed me Alfonso's letter. You spoke of ending the Naples war quickly. Of the cost in coin and sons. This morning, I learned Your Majesty visited the Consell de Cent and gave them a royal charter promising equal treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's ports. The merchants are delighted. Don Guillem de Vic speaks of 'new beginnings.' Bishop Climent Sapera has apparently rediscovered his faith. Your Majesty moves quickly. In two days, you have done more for Aragonese interests than most visiting kings manage in a month. So I ask myself: why? What does the King of Castile want from Aragón that he works so hard to charm us?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Who is to say that it is not Aragon who is charming me? The trade arrangements are reciprocal and Castilian merchants benefit from it as well when visiting Aragonese ports. And it is the bishop himself who discovered his calling again. There is nothing more beautiful than someone coming before God in humility. But I must confess that there is the matter of succession looming over us. If fate would have me be king of Aragon, then I want Aragon to know me. And I will want to know Aragon. That seems to be what everyone is asking me. Will I make Aragon a subject of Castile? Will I change trade arrangements? Will I honour existing feudal contracts? All while my cousin is still alive and well and will be hopefully for many years to come.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars listens without interruption. His weathered face reveals little—a man who has learned to keep his thoughts behind stone walls. When Juan finishes, the Count is silent for a long moment. He rises from his chair and moves to the window, looking out at the courtyard below.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks plainly. I respect that. Most men in your position would offer reassurances. Promises. Vows that nothing will change. You admit the truth—that you are here to be seen. To prepare for what may come. But Your Majesty will forgive me if I have heard kings speak of 'knowing' realms before. My grandfather heard Pedro of Castile speak of knowing Aragón. It did not end well for anyone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair but does not sit. He stands behind it, hands resting on its back.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: You ask what everyone fears. I will tell you what I fear. I fear that my sons will die in Italy for a crown Alfonso will never wear. I fear that Aragonese gold will continue flowing south while our mountain villages empty. I fear that when Alfonso finally falls from a Neapolitan wall or catches Roman fever, the man who inherits will see Aragón as a treasury to be raided for Castilian ambitions. Your Majesty has sent forty thousand florins to support Alfonso's Italian campaign. Catalan ships carry Castilian gold to fund a war that has already cost me a nephew and three cousins' sons. So when Your Majesty speaks of wanting to know Aragón—I must ask: do you wish to know us as partners? Or as the next source of men and money for the next war?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What would you do then? End the war? Capitulate? Will the Anjou accept a white peace? Or will they demand concessions? What would you do?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars' jaw tightens. The question has landed where Juan intended it. He is silent for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice is quieter—harder.

exchanges.speaker: hug_roger_iii
exchanges.text: What would I do. Your Majesty asks me to solve in a sentence what Alfonso has failed to solve in twelve years. I would not have started it. But that counsel comes too late by a decade. If it were mine to decide? I would negotiate. Not capitulate—negotiate. René of Anjou is not his brother. He has Provence to manage, a claim to Naples he cannot enforce alone, and less stomach for endless war than Louis had. Would he accept a white peace? No. But he might accept a partition. Alfonso keeps Calabria and Sicily. René takes Naples itself. Both claim the title, neither fights for it. It is ugly. It satisfies no one fully. But it stops the bleeding. Your Majesty has influence with Alfonso now. Castilian gold speaks loudly. If you counseled partition rather than total victory... But that is not what Your Majesty has done. You have sent florins and ships to help Alfonso win. So I ask again—what manner of king will you be to us?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You make an important point. The war should not have started in the first place. But we are past this now. You say that the war has cost Aragon gold and blood. A sentiment I share, the war has gone on for long enough. I have given Alfonso support in order to bring the war to a conclusion, not to let it drag along. I will visit him this year on my way to Constantinople and will council his on the situation. I will tell him that the war has to end, that ten years of war has drained his kingdom and he can ask no more of his subjects. Hopefully he will listen to me. Even if he cannot take all of Naples, the war has now come to a conclusion.

encounters.recap: Count Pallars confronts Juan about his true intentions in Aragón, expressing fear that Juan sees the realm as a source of men and money for future wars. Juan admits the succession question openly and promises to counsel Alfonso to end the Italian war when he visits him en route to Constantinople. The conversation reveals the deep tensions between Aragonese war-weariness and Juan's previous financial support for Alfonso's campaign.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: You will counsel him to end the war. And you say the war must conclude, even without total victory. These are better words than I expected, Your Majesty. I will not pretend otherwise. But words are easy. Alfonso has heard counsel before. His own wife has begged him to come home. María has managed his kingdom for four years while he chases Italian dreams. He does not listen.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: So I must ask: when will you see Alfonso? You say you travel to Constantinople—that is east. Naples is... Will you go to him before Constantinople? After? Will this counsel happen in weeks, or months, or next year? And what will you propose? You say the war must end. End how? Partition, as I suggested? Complete withdrawal? Some other arrangement? Telling Alfonso 'the war must end' means nothing. He believes he is winning. He will say 'yes, it will end—when I am crowned in Naples.' That is not what we need. Give me something concrete, Your Majesty. A route. A timeline. A proposal. Something I can take back to men who have buried their sons.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will travel to Rome first at the 1st of March. After my meeting with the pope, I will travel to Alfonso, wherever in Naples he is. I will tell him what I have told you. But I can only speak for myself, for Castille. I cannot speak on behalf of his own council or subjects. If you ask me to speak to my cousin on your behalf and maybe on behalf as well of others, then I could. But only with the blessing of the regency council. Otherwise, I would be meddling in the affairs of his kingdom. Remember that I hold no office or position in Aragon. If you want me to deliver a letter or statement from his kingdom concerning the state of the war and the kingdom, I can carry and deliver this message of course.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars' expression closes like a fortress gate. He is silent for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice is flat—not angry, which would be easier to address, but tired.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: A letter. I came here hoping to find a king who would use his influence. Who would tell Alfonso: the war ends, or the gold stops. Who would speak with the voice of a man who has power and is willing to wield it. Instead, Your Majesty offers to carry letters. To deliver messages. To wait for the regency council's blessing before speaking words that might actually matter.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: I have buried a nephew and three cousins' sons in Italian soil, Your Majesty. Their mothers did not ask me to find someone who respects proper channels. They asked me to find someone who would stop the bleeding. You say you hold no office in Aragon. This is true. But you hold forty thousand florins of influence with Alfonso. You hold a fleet in Valencia's harbor. You hold the papal favor that legitimizes his claim. These are not nothing. These are power. And you choose to wrap that power in procedure and wait for authorization.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: I thank Your Majesty for the audience. I will inform the Aragonese faction that the King of Castile is a man of careful words and proper process. God keep Your Majesty. And may your caution serve you better than boldness has served Alfonso.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do understand your position, and let me assure you that I will do what I can as best as I can to end the war. I have learned that smashing my fist on the table does not always yield the best results. I will pray for the fallen sons and the families who have lost them. Thank you for your time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars hesitates for a moment. Then he takes Juan's hand. His grip is firm—a soldier's grip—but brief. His eyes search Juan's face, looking for something. Whether he finds it is unclear.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: I believe you mean what you say, Your Majesty. I simply do not know if meaning well is enough. Pray for them. They would appreciate that.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He opens the door, bows once more to Lucia, and is gone. His footsteps echo down the corridor, measured and steady, carrying the weight of a man returning to deliver unwelcome news. The chamber is quiet after he leaves. Lucia rises from her chair, moving to stand beside Juan. She does not speak immediately—she has learned when words help and when they do not.

encounters.recap: Juan offers to counsel Alfonso to end the war and carry messages from the Aragonese faction, but insists on proper authorization from the regency council. Pallars, disappointed by Juan's cautious approach and reluctance to use his influence directly, leaves believing Juan means well but doubts his effectiveness in stopping the Italian war that has claimed so many Aragonese lives.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral rises from the heart of the Barri Gòtic like a prayer carved in stone. Gothic spires reach toward a winter sky, and the morning light filters through high windows, casting colored shadows across ancient flagstones. The royal party processes through the great doors: Juan and Lucia, Catalina carried by Inés, the household knights in their best doublets, Don Ramon and a contingent of Aragonese officials. The pews are full—word has spread that the King of Castile attends Mass, and Barcelona's faithful have come to see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Bishop Francesc Climent Sapera waits at the altar in full vestments. He looks... different. There is something in his bearing that was not there two days ago. A straightness to the spine. A clarity in the eyes. Before the Mass begins, Juan approaches the bishop with his request.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: The fallen sons of Aragón. And their families. Yes. Yes, I will pray for them. This is... not a prayer I expected a Castilian king to request. But it is a prayer that is long overdue.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Mass itself is... remarkable. Bishop Climent Sapera preaches not of politics or crowns, but of service. Of the difference between power wielded for glory and power wielded for others. He speaks of Christ washing the feet of his disciples—a king becoming a servant. He does not mention Juan by name. He does not need to.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And when he prays for the fallen sons—reading the names of those Barcelona families have lost in Italy, names he has clearly gathered in the night—something breaks open in the cathedral. Weeping. Not performative grief, but the raw sound of wounds finally acknowledged. An old woman in black clutches her rosary and sobs. A grey-haired man bows his head, shoulders shaking. Somewhere near the back, a young widow holds her children close. The prayer continues for nearly ten minutes. Name after name. Family after family.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Afterward, as the congregation files out into the morning light, Juan notices several things: The Count of Pallars stands near the back of the cathedral. He was not there when the Mass began. His weathered face is unreadable, but he has not left. Don Guillem de Vic hovers near the doors, looking uncertain—the Naples prayer was not what the Neapolitan faction expected from their new ally. And María—Queen María—stands in a side chapel, alone, a candle flickering before her. She has been crying.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Long. Very long. The man talked and talked. People were sad. The lady cried. Why sad, Papa? Why the people crying?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Sometimes, people die. That means they leave and never come back. That makes us all sad, especially if we love them very much. Would you be sad if I would leave and never come back?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No. Papa not leave. Papa stay. Catalina not sad. Papa not go away. Papa promise. The crying lady. Her papa went away? Her papa not come back?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The children's papa did not come back. They are very sad and so is the mama. If this happens we are all sad with them.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Sad with them. Catalina sad with them too? Mama. We give the crying lady a crostata? Papa stay and be sad with Catalina if... if someone goes away.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Catalina, what do we do when we are sad with someone else? We have no crostata here so we cannot give one. What else can we do? Can we give them a hug?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: A hug. But... Catalina not know her. Strangers. Inés says strangers are... Papa come too? Okay. Catalina give hug. Papa and Mama come.

encounters.recap: Juan requests Bishop Climent Sapera pray for the fallen sons of Aragón during Mass at Barcelona Cathedral. The bishop's powerful sermon and prayer for the war dead moves the congregation to tears, creating a moment of profound grief and healing. Juan's young daughter Catalina learns about death and compassion, ultimately deciding to offer comfort to grieving strangers with her parents' support.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches out, wanting to be set down. Her small hand finds Juan's and grips it tightly. Across the cathedral, the old woman in black has noticed the royal family's attention. She freezes, uncertain, clutching her rosary. Her daughter—or granddaughter—beside her looks equally bewildered. María remains in the chapel doorway, watching. The Count of Pallars has not moved from the back of the cathedral. The moment holds, waiting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina walks three steps toward the widow, her small hand gripping Juan's fingers tightly. Then she stops. The old woman in black looms before her—a stranger in dark clothes, face wet with tears, eyes red and swollen. The daughter beside her stares down at the approaching princess with barely concealed alarm. Catalina's courage evaporates. She spins and buries her face against Juan's leg, arms wrapping around his knee. A small whimper escapes her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral seems to hold its breath. The widow stands frozen, uncertain—should she kneel? Approach? Retreat? A king has walked toward her with his child and now the child clings to him in obvious distress.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your—Your Majesty, the widow manages, dropping into an unsteady curtsy. Her daughter follows suit, nearly stumbling. We are—I am honored—I do not— She trails off, lost. Catalina refuses to look up. Her small shoulders tremble. Lucia moves closer, her hand finding Catalina's back, murmuring something soft and reassuring. But the moment has curdled. What was meant to be simple grace has become awkward theater—a king standing in the middle of a cathedral with a frightened toddler attached to his leg and a bewildered widow unsure whether she has somehow given offense.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Forgive us, Your Majesty, she says quickly. My mother is... it has been a difficult morning. We should not take more of your time—

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It's allright. Catalina felt sad for you for losing your husband and father. She is still very young and sometimes a bit shy. I have been praying for you and families like yours and will continue to do so. Hopefully the war will finally be over.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The widow's hands tremble as she clutches her rosary. Up close, Juan can see the depth of the lines etched into her face—not old, but aged by grief. She might be forty. She looks sixty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: My husband, she says, her voice barely a whisper. And my son. Both. The daughter's hand tightens on her mother's arm. The widow's eyes flicker to Catalina, still hiding her face against Juan's shoulder. Something softens in her expression—the universal recognition of a mother seeing a frightened child. She is beautiful, the widow manages. Your daughter. She is... She cannot finish. Tears spill down her cheeks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Thank you, Your Majesty. For the prayers. For— She gestures vaguely toward the altar, toward where the bishop read the names. No one has... we have not heard their names spoken in church before. Not once. Not in three years. She curtsies again, unsteady, clearly desperate to flee but unsure if she has permission. God keep Your Majesty, she whispers. And your little one. Keep her safe. Keep her... Her voice breaks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The daughter steps in, supporting her mother's elbow. Thank you, Your Majesty, she says quietly, her eyes unreadable. We will pray for your family as well. It is not warm. It is not cold. It is the response of people who do not know what to make of a king who approaches them in a cathedral—who cannot tell if this is genuine or performance, and who are too exhausted by grief to parse the difference. They retreat toward the doors, the daughter guiding her mother with gentle hands.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lady still sad, Papa

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It's allright love. We dont have to give hugs or crostatas to everyone who is sad.

roll.outcome: Catalina loses courage. She hides behind Juan's leg, suddenly shy. The moment becomes awkward. The widow curtsies uncertainly, unsure what is expected. The gesture, though well-meant, falls flat.

encounters.recap: Juan attempts to comfort a grieving widow by having Catalina approach her, but the toddler becomes frightened and hides against her father's leg. The encounter becomes awkward, though Juan manages to salvage it somewhat by speaking gently with the widow about her losses and offering prayers. The widow reveals she lost both husband and son in the war, and expresses gratitude that their names were finally spoken in church.

encounters.location: Barcelona, Don Guillem de Vic's Residence

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Guillem straightens as Juan approaches, composing his features into something resembling courtly ease. It does not quite succeed.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Majesty. A... powerful Mass. The bishop spoke well. And the prayer for the fallen— Very moving.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: I have prepared the letters Your Majesty requested. Introductions to the Gualbes banking family. A framework for financial cooperation between Castilian and Catalan merchant houses. I was not certain... that is, I did not know if today was still appropriate to discuss such matters. Given the tone of the morning.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We are happy to review the letters with you, although we trust your instincts in these matters. Regarding the prayers, know that I am committed to continued aid to Alfonso to finish the war. But must never close our eyes to the costs of war. Don't you agree?

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: The costs of war. Yes. Of course, Your Majesty. War is... costly. I confess I did not expect— The Neapolitan faction has perhaps focused on the prize. Naples. The crown. The Mediterranean trade that flows from victory. We speak less of the price.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: My own cousin died at Ponza. When Alfonso was captured. I have not thought of him in... some time. There is always the next letter to write. The next alliance to secure. The next ship to fund. You are asking if I can hold both things at once. The necessity of victory and the weight of what victory costs. I do not know if I have done so before. But I take Your Majesty's point.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Guillem's residence is a fine townhouse near the Plaça del Rei—not ostentatious, but comfortable. Catalan practicality over Castilian grandeur. The letters are well-crafted. Introductions to the Gualbes family emphasizing mutual benefit. A framework for joint ventures in the Granada trade. Careful language that commits to cooperation without surrendering leverage.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We visit him and approve the letters there. Then we spend the next few days relaxing and acquainting ourselves with Catalan customs and sports.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Don Guillem de Vic to review trade correspondence, including letters to the Gualbes banking family and frameworks for Castilian-Catalan merchant cooperation. The conversation reveals Don Guillem's internal conflict between supporting the war effort and acknowledging its human costs, particularly after Juan's prayer for fallen soldiers. Juan approves the well-crafted letters and plans to spend coming days experiencing Catalan culture.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The enormous painted figures—a king and queen, a Moor and a Christian knight, fantastical creatures three times the height of a man—sway through Barcelona's narrow streets on the shoulders of hidden carriers. Drums pound. Pipes wail. The crowd surges and cheers.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Big people! Very big people!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She insists on being held aloft to see better, then insists on being put down to dance, then insists on being picked up again when the dragon gegant passes too close and she loses her nerve. Lucia laughs more than Juan has heard in weeks.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Barcelonans notice their visitors. Word spreads through the crowd: the Castilian king, the one who conquered Granada, he came to our festival. Some press closer to see. Others offer sweets to the little princess. An old woman presses a ribbon into Catalina's hands—a blessing, she says, for la princesita de la cuerda.

exchanges.speaker: arnau_despujol
exchanges.text: Thirty oars each side. Lateen sail for speed. Ram-prow reinforced with bronze.

exchanges.speaker: arnau_despujol
exchanges.text: Your Majesty knows ships.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am learning. Castile has never been a naval power. That must change.

exchanges.speaker: arnau_despujol
exchanges.text: If Your Majesty ever wishes to send shipwrights to study our methods... Barcelona's techniques are no secret to those who ask properly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan listens more than he speaks. He asks about trade routes, shipping costs, the challenges of dealing with Italian city-states. He does not promise. He does not commit. He learns.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: A good kill.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The falcon did the work.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: A modest king. Unusual.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: The council meets in four days. I have spoken with Don Ramon about the message to Alfonso. We are... drafting language.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Fish! Big fish!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Bird! Dead bird!

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Smell bad!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The market vendors are charmed. Word spreads. By afternoon, someone has given Catalina a small basket of candied almonds, a ribbon for her hair, and a tiny wooden cat that a craftsman carved on the spot.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon
exchanges.text: From His Majesty King Alfonso. Addressed to Her Majesty the Regent.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon
exchanges.text: Her Majesty wishes to inform His Majesty of Castile that the council meeting will proceed as planned. His Majesty's presence is... welcome.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Are you ready?

encounters.recap: Over nine days in Barcelona, Juan participates in the Festa de Sant Pau, visits shipyards and markets, hunts with Aragonese nobles, and builds relationships with local merchants and craftsmen. Catalina charms the citizens while the Count of Pallars begins to warm to Juan. María receives a letter from Alfonso and declares Juan's presence at the upcoming council 'welcome.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council chamber of the Palau Reial is smaller than Juan expected—intimate, even. A rectangular table of dark oak dominates the space, surrounded by high-backed chairs bearing the arms of Aragón. Tapestries depicting the conquest of Valencia line the walls. Morning light streams through narrow windows. The councillors are already assembled when Juan and Lucia enter.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. Your Majesty. The Council of Aragón welcomes you as honored guests.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The word guests carries weight. She gestures to two chairs set slightly apart from the table—visible, included, but not of the council.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Please. Be seated.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Her Majesty the Regent has prepared an agenda for today's proceedings. With Your Majesty's permission?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María nods.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: First: the matter of trade cooperation between the kingdoms, including the recent agreements with the Consell de Cent. Second: the Constantinople expedition and Castile's intentions regarding aid to the Emperor. Third: the Naples campaign and its... current state. Her Majesty has ruled that discussion of succession, inheritance, or the formal union of crowns shall be reserved until King Alfonso has been consulted.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Around the table, eyes flicker toward Juan. Watching. Measuring.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: Does Your Majesty of Castile have any questions before we proceed?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No questions. If I may thank the council for inviting me and my queen. We will be honoured observers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María's expression remains neutral, but something in her posture eases—barely perceptible. Juan has accepted the boundaries.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The council thanks Your Majesty for your courtesy. The first matter. Trade cooperation.

exchanges.speaker: ramon_de_perellos
exchanges.text: The Consell de Cent has provided a summary of their recent agreements with His Majesty of Castile. Equal treatment for Catalan merchants in Granada's ports. Reciprocal treatment for Castilian merchants in Barcelona. A commitment to host an international trading conference. Don Guillem de Vic has also prepared agreements with the Gualbes banking family establishing frameworks for financial cooperation.

exchanges.speaker: viscount_of_rocaberti
exchanges.text: A moment. Before we celebrate agreements made outside this council's authority, perhaps we should understand what was actually promised.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns to face Juan directly for the first time.

exchanges.speaker: viscount_of_rocaberti
exchanges.text: Your Majesty wrote a letter to Castilian port officials. Signed and sealed in Barcelona, in the hall of the Consell de Cent. A letter establishing trade policy for Granada. Policy that affects Aragonese merchants. Did Your Majesty consult this council before signing? Did Your Majesty consult the Regent? Or did Your Majesty simply... decide?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is very quiet. The moment stretches. The Viscount's question hangs in the air. Around the table, councillors watch—some looking at Juan, others at María. Don Guillem's hand has frozen over his documents. María regards Juan for a long moment. Her expression is unreadable. Then she inclines her head, the barest fraction.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile may respond to the Viscount's question.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It is true what you say. I have indeed written a letter to my officials in Castille. An act to address concerns of Aragonese merchants and done in full openness and transparency. I have nothing to hide. But I think the question the count is actually asking is this: Is Juan undermining the authority of both the regency council and the king himself? Would he not have asked permission before writing to his own court? To those questions I say this. I fully respect the authority of both the king and this council. Witnesses to the meeting can attest that I specifically stated this publicly. Maria and king Alfonso know of my ambition to improve christian trade and my policies should come as no surprise. I would never draft policies regarding a kingdom other than my own. But when it concerns my own kingdom, I require no permission from other kingdoms as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence that follows Juan's words is absolute. Rocabertí opens his mouth to respond—

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María's voice cuts through the chamber like a blade. Every head turns. The Regent has risen from her chair, the chain of office glinting in the morning light. Her eyes are fixed on the Viscount, and there is ice in them.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Viscount Rocabertí. Did I hear you correctly? Did you just question a sovereign king's right to instruct his own officials in his own kingdom?

exchanges.speaker: viscount_of_rocaberti
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I merely—

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You merely suggested that the King of Castile requires our permission to govern Castile. You have insulted a crowned monarch. In my council. Under my authority. His Majesty of Castile came to this council as an honored guest. He accepted conditions. He has shown this body respect that—that he did not owe us. And you repay that courtesy by questioning his sovereignty? The letter His Majesty wrote instructs Castilian officials to treat Catalan merchants as equals. As equals. Is there anyone here who wishes to object to that? Anyone who believes our merchants should be treated worse in Granada's ports?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I thought not. His Majesty of Castile has answered the question satisfactorily. The matter is closed. Don Ramon, proceed with the agenda.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns to Juan. For a moment, their eyes meet. Something passes between them—not warmth, not yet, but something closer to recognition. The Count of Pallars catches Juan's eye across the table. He nods. Once. Barely perceptible.

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: The potential is significant. Granada's trade alone could generate returns of fifteen to twenty percent annually for participating houses—both Catalan and Castilian.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: And the Church's interests? The tithes from this new commerce—how are they to be divided between dioceses?

exchanges.speaker: guillem_de_vic
exchanges.text: That... would require further consultation, Your Excellency.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_girona
exchanges.text: Indeed it would. I trust such consultation will occur before agreements are finalized.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: So noted. The trade agreements are accepted in principle, pending resolution of Church matters. The second item. Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: We have heard reports that His Majesty of Castile has committed substantial forces to Constantinople's defense. One thousand knights. Sixty thousand florins. We have also heard that His Majesty intends to travel there personally. Aragón has interests in the eastern Mediterranean. Our merchants trade in Constantinople. Our ships sail those waters. If Castile commits to a major military expedition in waters where Aragonese vessels operate, this council should understand the implications.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: And the costs. Another crusade. Another war requiring gold and men. We have experience with such ventures.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile may speak to the Constantinople matter, if he wishes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me state that I am not on crusade to fight the Ottomans. I am going to Constantinople to aid fellow Christians in need. This is publicly known but let me repeat the three options I will present to the Greeks. I will offer them sanctuary in my kingdom. They can leave their city and prevent further bloodshed in a war that can never be won. Constantinople will be no more, but its memory will live on.

encounters.recap: Juan faces the Aragonese Regency Council as an honored guest with limited authority. When Viscount Rocabertí challenges his right to write trade instructions to his own officials, Juan defends himself directly, prompting María to intervene decisively against the Viscount for questioning royal sovereignty. The council accepts trade agreements in principle and begins discussing Juan's Constantinople expedition.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me state that I am not on crusade to fight the Ottomans. I am going to Constantinople to aid fellow Christians in need. I will offer them sanctuary in my kingdom. If they refuse to leave, I will repair their walls as promised and wish them good luck and leave with my men. Only if I think we can really win, if not only Castille, but also other christian kingdoms are serious about committing to war with the Ottomans, will I commit to war. Either way, the Greeks have asked for help and I have responded. How they wish to continue is up to them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber stirs as Juan finishes. Councillors exchange glances—calculating, assessing.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
exchanges.text: If Constantinople's trade survives—and if Castilian forces help ensure it survives—Catalan merchants stand to benefit. The eastern routes are... There are commercial considerations.

exchanges.speaker: count_of_pallars
exchanges.text: Three options. Evacuation. Repair and departure. Or war, if others commit. This is... not what I expected to hear.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: His Majesty speaks of grand strategy. Of Ottoman banners on Christian coasts. But I asked about Aragonese interests. Our merchants. Our ships. Our sailors. If Castilian warships operate in waters where Catalan trading vessels sail, what arrangements exist to prevent... confusion?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Gentlemen. His Majesty of Castile has outlined his intentions. He has not asked Aragón for troops, ships, or gold. The question before this council is whether Aragón has specific concerns that should be communicated.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: First. What arrangements will His Majesty make to ensure Catalan vessels are recognized and protected by Castilian naval forces? Second. If the city falls, does Castile accept any obligation to evacuate Aragonese subjects? Third. If Castile decides to withdraw, what warning will His Majesty provide?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do your ships not carry the flag of your kingdom? I assure you that my captains know of your flags and will not regard you as the enemy. You have my word that I shall grant aid and sanctuary to any Aragonese brothers who wish to leave. I will use my fleet to break any blockade and make sure everyone gets home safely should this occur.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: These are not small promises, Your Majesty. A king's word in a council chamber is one thing. A treaty signed and sealed is another. If His Majesty were willing to formalize these commitments—a written undertaking, perhaps...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course sister, I will sign this document immediately if it serves to provide assurance to this council. Maybe we could include that Aragon shall also aid in the evacuation to the best of their ability, should such a situation occur? It seems fair to me since both kingdoms share the same interest.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: This council cannot commit the Crown of Aragón to military obligations without the King's consent. However. If His Majesty is willing to sign a document pledging Castilian protection... this council can recommend to King Alfonso that Aragón offer reciprocal assistance.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: If I arrive with Castille already committed and a recommendation from this council that Alfonso reciprocate, I may bring him in a difficult position. If this council can not commit to sign as well, then I propose I discuss this matter with the king directly so we may both sign at the same time.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber falls silent. María stares at Juan. For a long moment, her composed mask slips—not into anger or suspicion, but something closer to surprise.

exchanges.speaker: berenguer_de_bardaxi
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile has just voluntarily surrendered an advantage.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: You would have had us in a corner. Castile committed, the council recommending, Alfonso with no graceful way to refuse. And you chose not to.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon
exchanges.text: Then the matter of Constantinople shall be noted as follows: His Majesty of Castile will discuss mutual protection of subjects with King Alfonso directly. This council will prepare a letter outlining our considerations and concerns.

encounters.recap: Juan presents his three-option approach to Constantinople to the Aragonese council, emphasizing caution over crusading glory. When pressed on protecting Aragonese interests, he offers written commitments but suggests mutual obligations. Rather than forcing Aragón into an awkward position, he voluntarily proposes to negotiate directly with Alfonso as equals, earning unexpected respect from the council.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You would have had us in a corner. Castile committed, the council recommending, Alfonso with no graceful way to refuse. And you chose not to.

exchanges.speaker: don_ramon
exchanges.text: Then the matter of Constantinople shall be noted as follows: His Majesty of Castile will discuss mutual protection of subjects with King Alfonso directly. This council will prepare a letter outlining our considerations and concerns for His Majesty to carry. Is this acceptable?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The third item. Naples.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The room tenses. This is the wound that has bled Aragón for twelve years.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Count Pallars. You indicated that you and Don Ramon have been drafting language regarding a message to the King. Will you present it?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars rises from his chair. He is not a man given to theatrics—his movements are deliberate, economical. He produces a folded document from his doublet and spreads it on the table before him.

exchanges.speaker: pallars
exchanges.text: This council has long debated how to address the Naples question with His Majesty King Alfonso. Some believe we should demand immediate withdrawal. Others believe we should support the campaign to its conclusion. For twelve years, we have done neither—sending gold and men while wringing our hands. Don Ramon and I have attempted to draft language that this council might actually agree upon. Language that speaks truth without ultimatum. That honors the King's sacrifices while acknowledging the kingdom's exhaustion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Pallars reads the draft letter to Alfonso, requesting he weigh the costs of continuing the Naples campaign after twelve years of war have strained the kingdom's treasury and noble houses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber is silent. Don Guillem's face has gone pale. The Viscount of Rocabertí looks as though he wants to speak but is restraining himself. The Bishop of Girona studies his folded hands.

exchanges.speaker: don_guillem
exchanges.text: The letter is... eloquent. But I wonder if 'swiftly' is not already within reach. His Majesty's recent victories—Calabria turning to his banner, Queen Joanna's envoys—

exchanges.speaker: pallars
exchanges.text: Queen Joanna has sent envoys before. Twice she has offered adoption. Twice she has revoked it. Joanna's word is written in sand. The situation has been 'different now' for twelve years, Don Guillem. My nephew's bones lie in Italian soil. Three cousins' sons. How many more until the situation is 'different enough'?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: This letter asks my husband to consider abandoning his life's work. The crown he has fought for since before our marriage. The dream that has sustained him through capture, through humiliation, through years of exile from his own kingdom. And yet. I have governed Aragón for four years in his absence. I have signed the levies. I have heard the widows' petitions. I have watched the treasury dwindle and the noble houses grow restless. The letter is not wrong.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile has indicated he will meet with King Alfonso. He has offered to carry messages from this council. Perhaps His Majesty has thoughts on how such a message might be received. If he wishes to share them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The council asks how this message might be received. I think it will achieve nothing. The message states that if the war is won swiftly - an unlikely outcome despite the recent victories - he should conclude and win it. But if it takes another decade, he should sue for peace. Also an unlikely outcome. I think that it will take another year to fully secure victory. Alfonso believes he can win in one year and this letter will not change anything about this I believe. Personally, I will assess the situation and see with my own eyes if indeed the war is effectively won. If it is not, I will counsel him to sue for peace immediately.

exchanges.speaker: pallars
exchanges.text: The letter speaks for this council. It says what we believe, what we have paid, what we fear. His Majesty's assessment and counsel are his own matter—between kings. I would not discard the letter simply because His Majesty will also speak. But perhaps... the letter need not travel with His Majesty. Perhaps it should go through other channels. Royal courier. So that it arrives as this council's voice, separate from whatever His Majesty chooses to say.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Is this acceptable? The Naples letter sent by royal courier, arriving before or alongside His Majesty's visit, but not carried by his hand?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María counts the votes. Four in favor - Pallars, Don Berenguer de Bardaxí, the Bishop of Girona, and Rocabertí. Don Guillem opposes. The Regent abstains.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The letter will be sent. By royal courier. Within the week.

exchanges.speaker: pallars
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile came to this council as a guest. He accepted conditions that no sovereign was obligated to accept. He answered challenges with patience. He offered commitments and then—declined to press advantage when he might have. I have been in councils for thirty years. I have seen kings bluster and threaten and demand. I have seen precious few listen. I would have the record note that the King of Castile conducted himself with honor in these proceedings.

encounters.recap: The Aragonese council debates a letter to King Alfonso urging him to reconsider the costly Naples campaign. Juan offers to personally assess the situation and counsel Alfonso if needed, but predicts the letter will achieve nothing. The council votes 4-1 to send the letter by royal courier rather than having Juan carry it. Pallars concludes by formally commending Juan's honorable conduct during the proceedings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber empties slowly. Soon only Juan, Lucia, and María remain—and Don Ramon, hovering near the door with his papers. María stands at the head of the table, her hand resting on the regent's chair.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
