exchanges.text: Brother. Will you walk with me? There is a garden. We could speak. Just the two of us. If your queen permits.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course Maria. Will you give us a moment Lucia?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises from her chair with quiet grace. Her eyes meet Juan's—a moment of wordless understanding passes between them.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Of course. Sister. Take all the time you need. I will be with Catalina. She will want to hear about the very important meeting where Papa sat in a big chair and talked to important people.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A soft smile, and she withdraws. Don Ramon holds the door for her, then glances at María.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Leave us, Don Ramon. The documents can wait an hour.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The administrator bows and departs, closing the heavy door behind him. The council chamber falls silent. Dust motes drift in the afternoon light slanting through the narrow windows. María moves toward a small door half-hidden behind a tapestry. The garden is small—an intimate courtyard enclosed by high walls, invisible from the rest of the palace. A fountain murmurs at its center. Winter roses climb a trellis, their blooms sparse but fragrant. Stone benches line the paths. María walks to the fountain and stands with her back to Juan, looking down at the water. For a long moment, she does not speak.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I watched you today. In the council. You could have pressed us. On Constantinople. On the trade agreements. On a dozen small things where you held advantage. Why didn't you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Advantage or imbalance also creates conflict. I seek none with Aragon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María is still for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Conflict. I have spent four years managing conflict. Between the factions. Between what Alfonso wants and what the kingdom can give. Between what I am told to do and what I know must be done. You hurt me, Juan. When you first came. I know. Lucia told me you understood. That you learned. I watched you prove it today—with the Consell, with Don Ramon, with the council itself. But I need to understand something.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She moves to a stone bench and sits, her hands folded in her lap. She looks up at him, and for a moment she is not the Regent of Aragón. She is his sister. A woman in her thirties, childless, governing a kingdom for a husband who may never return, watching her brother build an empire while she holds together what remains.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: You speak of unity. Of kingdoms joining to become something new. Of neither holding dominance. But you are King of Castile. Conqueror of Granada. Heir presumptive to this throne I sit upon in Alfonso's absence. If Alfonso dies—when Alfonso dies—you will have everything. Castile. Aragón. Perhaps Naples, if his war succeeds. The largest Christian kingdom since Charlemagne. What happens to me, Juan? In this vision of yours. What place is there for a childless queen whose husband is gone and whose brother wears all the crowns?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan embraces her. María stiffens at first—the reflex of a woman who has held herself rigid for four years, who cannot afford softness. Then something breaks. She sags against him. A shudder runs through her. She does not weep—perhaps she has forgotten how—but her breath comes ragged, and her hands grip the fabric of his doublet like a drowning woman gripping driftwood.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are my sister Maria. I want nothing but for you to be happy. You already told me you do not want an estate somewhere to live in peace. What do you want? If you are interested in statecraft, I need many governors I can trust. Or you can stay at my court. Watch Catalina and my other children grow up. Educate them, be their aunt. But I do not know what you would want Maria. All I can say is that I will take care of you. What do you want?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long moment passes. When she pulls back, her eyes are dry but reddened. She turns away, walking a few steps toward the winter roses. Her hand reaches out to touch a bloom, then withdraws.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_aragon
exchanges.text: What do I want. Alfonso wanted Naples. So I wanted Alfonso to have Naples. Father wanted a strong alliance with Castile. So I wanted to be a good wife, a good queen, a good regent. No one has ever asked me what I want, Juan. Not once. Not in thirty-four years. You offer me an estate. A governorship. A place at your court, watching your children grow. These are kind offers. Generous offers. The offers of a brother who wishes to take care of his sister. I have governed Aragón for four years. I have held together a kingdom while its king chased dreams in Italy. I have managed factions that wanted to tear each other apart. I have signed levies and heard petitions and made decisions that cost men their lives and livelihoods. And you offer me... an estate. Children to watch. A quiet corner where I will not be in the way. Is that what you see when you look at me, brother? A woman to be taken care of? Given a comfortable place and a gentle purpose?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: No, not at all! I just offered them up as possibilities. And I just said you do NOT want an estate somewhere. I love you sister. I will never forget how you taught me about love when we met four years ago when I fell in love with that noble woman. It made me realize how important family is and how much I needed a sister. I love you Maria, but please let me love you. I cannot give what I cannot see. You have not answered my question. What do you want?

encounters.recap: Juan and María share a private conversation in the regent's garden. María confronts Juan about her future role as his power grows, expressing fear of being marginalized despite her years of governing Aragón. When Juan offers various possibilities for her future, she rejects them as condescending charity, revealing her deep struggle with never having been asked what she truly wants for herself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I love you sister. I will never forget how you taught me about love when we met four years ago when I fell in love with that noble woman. It made me realize how important family is and how much I needed a sister. I love you Maria, but please let me love you. I cannot give what I cannot see. You have not answered my question. What do you want?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María opens her mouth. Closes it. She turns away again, her arms crossing over her chest. For a long moment she is silent, and when she speaks, her voice is rough.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I don't know. I don't know, Juan. I have never— When I was a girl, I wanted to ride horses and read books about faraway places. Then I was told I would marry Alfonso, and I wanted to be a good wife. Then Alfonso left for Naples, and I wanted to be a good regent. Then the years passed, and I wanted— I wanted a child. Just one. Something that was mine. Something I had not been given or assigned or obligated to.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She stands rigid, her back to him.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: God did not grant me that. So I governed. Because governing was what was needed. Because if I could not be a mother, I could at least be useful. And now you ask me what I want, and I stand here like a fool, because I have spent so long wanting what others needed me to want that I do not know if there is anything left underneath.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns. Her eyes are bright—not with tears, but with something fiercer. Anger, perhaps. Or fear.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: You want to give me something, brother? Then give me time. Time to answer a question I have never been allowed to ask myself. And if I find an answer—if I discover that what I want is something you cannot give, or something that frightens you, or something that does not fit neatly into your vision of unity and family— Will you still love me then?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maria. When I was struggling with matters of love, you spoke with such certainty. Such wisdom. I will never forget it. It surprises me you now seem so uncertain. Maybe it is so much easier to help others than we can help ourselves. Why don't you come and visit us tomorrow? Bring a crostata or better yet, a Catalan treat Catalina may like. I think it will do you much good. Family can see things other can not.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María stares at him. For a moment, something flickers across her face—a dozen emotions too quick to name. Surprise. Uncertainty. Something that might be the beginning of a smile, quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: A crostata. You are offering me... a crostata. And time with your daughter. I just told you that I do not know who I am. That I have spent my entire life being what others needed. That I am terrified of becoming irrelevant. And your answer is pastry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns away, her hand covering her mouth. Her shoulders shake. When she turns back, there are tears on her cheeks—but she is smiling. A strange, broken, genuine thing.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: You impossible man. You absolute fool. I pour out my heart and you invite me for crostatas. Yes. Fine. Tomorrow. I will bring ensaïmadas. They are Mallorcan. Catalina will make a mess of herself. The nurses will despair.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She steps forward and takes his hands.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I do not have answers yet, Juan. I may not have them before you sail. I may not have them for years. But I will... try. To find them. To ask the question. And yes. I will come tomorrow. To see your daughter. To meet your wife properly—not as a wounded queen, but as... As a sister. If she will have me.

encounters.recap: In an emotional breakthrough, María finally opens up about her lifelong struggle with never being allowed to want anything for herself, from childhood dreams to her desperate desire for a child. When Juan offers simple family connection through a visit with pastries, she breaks down in tears of recognition and agrees to come meet his family as a sister rather than a queen.

roll.outcome: Survives childhood healthy. Fortune and constitution carry her through to adulthood.

encounters.recap: A critical survival roll determines that Princess Catalina will survive the dangerous years of medieval childhood. Despite the high mortality rates of the 15th century, she will grow up healthy, living through occasional fevers and childhood ailments but ultimately reaching adulthood intact.

roll.outcome: Intelligence: 87 (Brilliant) - Temperament: 76 (Commanding) - Special Talent: 34 (Music/Voice) - Piety: 7 (Indifferent) - Beauty: 70 (Beautiful) - Voice Focus: 5 (Angelic singing voice)

encounters.recap: Character generation rolls for Princess Catalina reveal her future traits: exceptional intelligence and natural command presence, beautiful appearance, and a divine singing voice. However, she will lack genuine religious faith despite her musical gifts making her the finest sacred performer in Castile - creating a painful irony for her deeply devout father Juan II.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ensaïmadas arrive before María does. A servant brings them on a silver tray—spiraled pastries dusted with powdered sugar, their surfaces glistening with rendered pork fat in the Mallorcan style. The scent fills the nursery: butter, sweetness, something faintly exotic. Catalina's eyes grow very wide.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: What are those.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_zuniga
exchanges.text: Those are ensaïmadas, cariño. Your Aunt María is bringing them. We must wait for her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: But they are here.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_zuniga
exchanges.text: The pastries are here. Your aunt is not.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Catalina will guard them. Until Aunt María comes. So no one eats them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A noble sacrifice.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Yes. Very noble.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María arrives at the hour of Terce. She wears a simpler gown than yesterday—still fine, but less formal. The regent's chain of office is absent. Her hair is braided in a style Juan remembers from their childhood, before crowns and politics complicated everything. She hesitates at the nursery door. Lucia rises, crossing to meet her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_zuniga
exchanges.text: Sister. Thank you for coming.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I... brought ensaïmadas. For Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: AUNT MARÍA! I guarded them! The pastries! No one ate them! I was VERY NOBLE!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She collides with María's skirts, wrapping her arms around the queen's legs. María looks down at the small face beaming up at her. Something in her expression cracks.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Very well, little one. You guarded them. You should have the honor of first choice.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: This one. No. This one. The big one has more sugar.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: It does.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: But this one is more... swirly.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Also true.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Catalina will take... the swirly one. Because swirly is special. You take the big one. Because you are the queen and queens get the big ones.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Thank you, Catalina. That is very generous.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They settle around the small table—Juan, Lucia, María, and Catalina, with Inés hovering nearby. The ensaïmadas are everything promised: light, buttery, the sugar melting on the tongue. Catalina gets powdered sugar on her nose, her cheeks, somehow in her hair.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Aunt María, do you have a horse?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I do. Several, actually.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: What are their names?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Well, there is Estrella—that means 'star.' And Ventisco—

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: I have a horse. His name is Hidalgo. He is very brave. Can your horses jump?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I believe Estrella jumps quite well.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: Hidalgo jumps higher.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Shall we go horse riding later today? We still have some time. Catalina loves to ride on horses. We can watch the ships.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Horse riding. To watch the ships.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_zuniga
exchanges.text: Yes. The harbor is beautiful from the Montjuïc hill. And Catalina has been asking to see the big ships since we arrived.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: THE BIG SHIPS! With the sails! And the flags! Inés says they go very far away across the water!

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I... cannot remember the last time I rode for pleasure. There is always a procession, or a formal hunt, or some delegation to receive. Riding has become... another duty. But today there is no procession. No delegation. No council. I would like that. Very much.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: AUNT MARÍA IS COMING! We will see the ships AND the horses will jump AND— Aunt María, can you race?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I used to. When I was young.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_castile
exchanges.text: You are not that old. You can probably still go a little fast.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I suppose we shall find out.

encounters.recap: María visits Juan's family in their private apartments, sharing ensaïmadas with young Catalina. Through the child's innocent enthusiasm, María begins to soften from her formal regent role, rediscovering simple pleasures like family time and the prospect of riding horses for enjoyment rather than duty. The intimate breakfast leads to plans for a family outing to watch ships from Montjuïc hill.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María rides beside Lucia, their horses walking abreast. The Regent sits her saddle well—the muscle memory of a noblewoman trained from childhood—but there is something stiff in her posture. The body remembers; the spirit has forgotten why it once loved this. They pass through the Porta de Mar and the city falls away behind them. The road winds upward toward the hill of Montjuïc, the harbor spreading out below like a map painted in blue and white and the warm brown of wooden hulls. The wind freshens, carrying salt and tar and distant places.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: There! SHIPS! Many ships!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And there are. Dozens of vessels crowd the harbor—fishing boats and merchant carracks, sleek war galleys with their oars shipped, fat-bellied traders from Genoa and Venice and places beyond. The banners of a dozen nations flutter in the breeze. María reins up beside them, her eyes on the water.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I used to come here as a girl. Before I was married. I would watch the ships and wonder where they were going. I never found out.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You know Catalina, we will be going on a big ship and leave over the water in a few weeks time? We will travel for many days on the big ship.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: On the water? In a ship?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, cariño. A very big ship. With sails and flags, just like those.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: Will Hidalgo come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Hidalgo will stay here and rest. But there will be other horses where we are going.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: Will Mama come? Will Inés come? Will Aunt María come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Mama is coming. Yes, Inés too. Aunt María has to stay here. She has an important job. She takes care of Aragón while King Alfonso is away.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: But who takes care of Aunt María?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The wind gusts. A gull cries somewhere overhead. Lucia's horse shifts beneath her. María looks away, toward the ships, toward the horizon, toward all the places she wondered about as a girl and never saw.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: That is a very good question.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We shall take care of Maria while we are here ok? Im sure she will like that.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: Yes. We will take care of Aunt María. Aunt María, do you like crostatas?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: I... yes. I suppose I do.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: Good. Catalina will give you a crostata. And a hug. That is what we do when people are sad or need taking care of. Papa said we don't have to give hugs to everyone. But you are family. Family gets hugs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María's composure cracks. She turns her horse away slightly, one hand rising to her face. Her shoulders tremble. Lucia quietly moves her mount closer, placing a gentle hand on María's arm.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: Aunt María? Did Catalina say something wrong?

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: No, little one. No, you said something very right. Thank you, Catalina. I would very much like a crostata. And a hug. I cannot remember the last time someone offered me either.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: We will get crostatas on the way home. Papa will pay. He is the king. Kings have lots of money.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They find a baker in the Plaça del Pi, near the church of Santa Maria. The shop is small and warm, fragrant with sugar and butter and woodsmoke. The baker's wife nearly faints when she realizes who has entered her establishment. The crostata is produced—golden-brown, glistening with honey, studded with almonds. It is not the refined work of a palace kitchen. It is better. It is real.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They gather in María's private chambers rather than the formal apartments—smaller, warmer, less like a throne room. Cushions and chairs pulled close together. The crostata set on a table between them. No servants. No ceremony. Catalina has claimed a position on María's lap, which María accepted with an expression of stunned wonder, as if a wild bird had landed on her hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: You must take the first piece, Aunt María. Because you are the queen here. Then Papa, because he paid. Then Mama. Then Catalina. Then Catalina again, if there is more.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They eat. The crostata is sweet and sticky and imperfect and wonderful. Catalina gets honey on her chin, her fingers, somehow on her forehead. She chatters about ships and horses and whether fish know they are wet. At some point, María's arm settles around Catalina's small body—not stiffly, not formally, but naturally. As if it belongs there.

exchanges.speaker: catalina_of_trastamara
exchanges.text: Aunt María? You are not so sad anymore.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: No. No, I am not so sad anymore.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: María looks at Juan over the child's head. Her eyes are bright.

exchanges.speaker: maria_of_castile
exchanges.text: Thank you.

encounters.recap: During a family outing to view ships from Montjuïc, young Catalina's innocent questions about who cares for María touch the lonely Regent deeply. The child's offer of comfort through 'crostatas and hugs' breaks María's emotional barriers. They share a simple pastry together in María's private chambers, where she finds unexpected healing through Catalina's pure affection and the warmth of family connection.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Seven hundred knights in white tabards marked with the crosses of their orders—Santiago's red sword-cross, Calatrava's crimson fleur-de-lys cross, Alcántara's green cross—stand in formation on the fields beyond the city walls. They have been assembling for weeks, arriving in groups from their commanderies across Castile and Aragón. Veterans of the Granada campaign, most of them. Men who stormed the walls of Málaga and Loja, who stood in the breach at Alhama, who watched the Sultan's banner fall over the Alhambra. Now they prepare for a longer journey. Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The men are assembled for inspection.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Robles' expression tells Juan something is wrong before they reach the first rank. The inspection reveals the problems starkly. Sickness. A fever has swept through the camp over the past week. Nearly sixty men lie in the infirmary tents, shivering under blankets. Three have died. Supply Issues. A shipment of preserved meat from Valencia arrived spoiled. The replacement shipment is delayed—perhaps another week, perhaps longer. Morale. The waiting has worn on them. These are veterans of Granada—men who fought and won. Now they sit in muddy fields outside Barcelona while their commanders negotiate politics and their supplies rot.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty should be aware... There have been difficulties. The Order commanders blame each other for the supply failures. Santiago says Calatrava's quartermaster accepted the spoiled meat without proper inspection. Calatrava says Santiago's camp placement contaminated the water. Alcántara's men feel overlooked entirely—they claim their equipment requests have been ignored. The men need to see leadership, Your Majesty. They need to know this expedition has purpose. Right now, they see only confusion and sickness and delay.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The armor weighs on Juan's shoulders like memory. It is the same harness he wore at Málaga, at Loja, at the final assault on Granada's gates. The white banner of the crusade snaps in the February wind—the same banner that flew over Alhama, that was carried through the breach at Alcalá la Real. Six hundred and forty-three men able to stand assemble in ragged ranks. Some lean on their neighbors. The Santiago knight who coughed during inspection is there, pale as milk, swaying slightly but upright. Behind them, the infirmary tents. Sixty more men who will hear this speech through canvas walls.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers. We are about to embark on a great journey. A journey that will take us from Barcelona to Rome and beyond to Constantinople. Much is at stake. The church is divided and the eternal city, the last light of Christendom is about to be snuffed out. We have just won a great victory against the Moors and have done things no-one had deemed possible. We ended the reconquista. It was hard in the beginning. We have suffered setbacks and even defeats here and there. The muslims are hard fighters and they made us bleed made us suffer. Cut our supply lines. Left us hungry and miserable while we were sieging mighty walls. Right now, we are tired, sick. Maybe even hungry. Such is the fate of knights and soldiers. But have we not been here before? Have we not overcome hunger and pain? Yes! we have. We know what to do as well. We lack supplies, so we aquire more. We are sick, so we tend to our brothers until we are better. And when we are ready to move out, when we are ready to go on this incredible journey, only then we will leave. When I met the Greek delegation in Basel, they had given up all hope. No-one was going to help them. No-one had the courage, the will, the determination. No-one but the sons of Castille! We go where no-one else dared journey. We face what no-one else dared face. We fight for what everyone else seems to have forgotten. We know that when we raise our swords in the name of Christ, we serve a higher purpose. I stand before you today on the first day of this incredible journey to speak the words. Words that have carried us over blood-soaked fields and towards victory. Non nobis Domine!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: For a moment—a long, terrible moment—there is only silence. Then, from somewhere in the Santiago ranks, a voice answers: 'Non nobis Domine.' Another joins. Then another. The response spreads—but slowly, unevenly, like fire struggling to catch in wet kindling. It is not the thunder of Granada. It is not the roar that shook the walls of Málaga or echoed through the Alhambra's halls. It is tired men doing what they have been trained to do. Speaking words they remember because their bodies remember, even when their hearts are uncertain. The sick Santiago knight mouths the prayer, but no sound comes. His neighbor grips his arm to keep him upright.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: They answered, Your Majesty. That is something. But they need more than words now. They need to see the supply wagons arrive. They need to see the sick recover. They need to see that someone is solving the problems, not just acknowledging them. You have bought time, Your Majesty. Perhaps a week. Perhaps less. What would you have me do?

roll.outcome: Grudging acknowledgment. The response comes—'Non nobis Domine'—but muted, tired. The veterans remember Granada, but Constantinople feels different. Doubt lingers. The speech bought time, not belief.

encounters.recap: Juan inspects his 700 knights assembled for the Constantinople crusade but finds the camp in crisis—fever has struck sixty men, supplies have spoiled, and morale is broken. Despite donning his Granada armor and delivering an inspiring speech invoking their past victories, the men's response is lukewarm. The speech steadies them temporarily but does not restore their faith, leaving Juan with only days to solve the practical problems before losing them entirely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent is cramped, utilitarian—a campaign shelter, not a throne room. A table dominates the center, covered with supply manifests, maps, and the detritus of a troubled expedition. The canvas walls snap in the wind. Juan enters still in armor. Captain Robles follows, then the three Order commanders file in behind. They do not sit. No one has offered, and the tension in the air does not invite comfort.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Commanders.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty's speech was stirring. But speeches do not fill bellies or cure fevers. If we are to address problems, let us begin with who created them. Calatrava's quartermaster accepted meat that a blind man could smell was rotten—

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Santiago's camp placement put us downstream from a tanner's waste. My men did not poison the water. Yours did.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: If either of you had listened to Alcántara's concerns three weeks ago—

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Alcántara has one hundred men. This is not your expedition to command.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Enough! Lets focus on the problem. Care for the sick first. They are now taken care of in tents right? Could we not accomodate them in a hospital or grant them other and better accomodation?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent falls silent. The three commanders stand rigid, their accusations still hanging in the air like smoke. But Juan's voice—sharp, commanding—has cut through the noise.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is a hospital, Your Majesty. The Hospital de la Santa Creu, within the city walls. It is run by the Church—the canons of the Cathedral. It is one of the finest in Aragón. They have tended plague victims, pilgrims, soldiers. If anyone can help our sick, they can.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Moving sixty men through the city... it would be visible. Public. Word would spread that the expedition is weakened. That the King of Castile's knights are dying in camp before they even board ships.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: They are already dying in camp. Three dead. More to follow if we do nothing.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Alcántara speaks truth, for once. The tents are inadequate. Cold at night, damp, no proper drainage. The physicians do what they can, but... They need walls. Hearths. Clean water. Things we cannot provide in a field camp.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: If Her Majesty the Regent were to request the hospital's assistance—or if Your Majesty were to ask directly—I do not think they would refuse. The Church has been... favorable to Your Majesty's cause since the Granada campaign. Shall I send word to Don Ramon to arrange it? We could have the men moved by nightfall.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will secure the hospital for our brothers. Food is next. What are we missing? Both what we consume right now and what we need for the journey.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Robles spreads a supply manifest across the table, weighting the corners with a dagger and a cup.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: For current consumption, we are... adequate. Barely. Bread from Barcelona's bakers—that supply holds. Wine from local merchants. Cheese and oil. The men are not starving. But they are not eating well either. Morale suffers when soldiers see thin rations.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: My men have been on half-portions of meat for six days. The Alcántara quartermaster has been requesting resupply since before the fever struck. We were told to wait. We waited.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: For the voyage, the situation is worse. A sea journey from Barcelona to Rome—ten days to two weeks, depending on weather. Then Rome to Naples, if Your Majesty visits King Alfonso. Then onward to Constantinople—another three weeks, perhaps a month, with stops for water and provisions. We need, at minimum: Salted meat: Four hundred barrels. We have sixty-three. The Valencia shipment was to provide two hundred—all spoiled. The replacement is delayed. Ship's biscuit: Six hundred crates. We have four hundred. Sufficient if we resupply in Rome. Dried fish: Two hundred barrels. We have one hundred twenty. Wine: Eight hundred casks. We have six hundred. Sufficient. Dried legumes and grain: Three hundred sacks. We have two hundred. Olive oil and vinegar: Adequate. Fresh water barrels: The ships carry these. That is the fleet's concern, not ours.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The meat is the crisis. Without it, men weaken. Weak men sicken. Sick men die—especially at sea. Valencia failed us. We need another source. Quickly.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Barcelona's markets could provide some. But four hundred barrels for an army? We would drain the city. The Consell de Cent would not thank us for emptying their storehouses.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There are other options, Your Majesty. Tarragona has salting houses. Mallorca trades in preserved pork. We could send riders, ships, purchasing agents—but all of this takes time. And money. How long is Your Majesty willing to delay departure?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will have to pay either way. Can we send riders for other markets? And can we resupply in Naples and other cities we pass along the way?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Riders to Tarragona—one day there, one day back. If their salting houses have stock, we could see barrels arriving within the week. Mallorca requires a ship, but they export preserved pork throughout the Mediterranean. Two weeks, perhaps, if winds favor us. As for resupply along the way... yes. It is possible. Even advisable—fresh provisions keep men healthier than salt-stores alone.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Rome will be expensive. The papal court inflates prices for everything. But the markets there are vast—we can find what we need if we pay. Here is better. Alfonso's army has established supply lines. If His Majesty is visiting the King of Aragón, we could arrange provisions in advance. Neapolitan salt pork is serviceable. Not as good as Castilian, but it keeps.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Sicily. If we stop there. Messina has warehouses. Cheaper than Rome, better quality than Naples.

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: If we are dividing the supply burden across multiple ports... we need fewer barrels from Barcelona. Carry enough to reach Rome. Resupply there for Naples. Resupply in Naples for Constantinople. We stretch our coin further and reduce the risk of another spoilage.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: If we reduce our Barcelona requirement to... one hundred fifty barrels of salt meat instead of four hundred... combined with what we have... Achievable. Tarragona alone might provide that within a week. I can dispatch riders within the hour, Your Majesty. And send word ahead to Rome and Naples to prepare provisions for our arrival. We would need letters of credit. The Gualbes banking arrangements Don Guillem negotiated—they could facilitate payments in Rome and Naples without carrying chests of gold aboard ship.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: This could work.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: If we do not delay further. Every day in camp is another day for fever to spread.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I want to leave with enough meat in stock to last us a while. We can supplement our stock as we visit ports along the way. Send riders for more meat. I want to sail with around 250-300 barrels. Pay their price to secure this. And finally, we must adress the situation of half ration while we are still in friendly territory. Make sure the men have enough to eat and drink the coming days. They must regain their strength, it will not get easier. I will speak with my sister about how the men can be fed properly. Now, if we assume the sick will have proper accomodation, we are getting enouth supplies and the men have a full belly, are there other issues we should adress?

exchanges.speaker: vasco_de_orozco
exchanges.text: Equipment, Your Majesty. Alcántara requisitioned replacement armor and weapons six weeks ago. Twelve hauberks. Twenty swords. Horse tack for the mounted sergeants. We were told supplies were limited and priority went to the larger Orders. My men are patching rust with prayer.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of... command structure. At Granada, Your Majesty led. The Orders followed. Clear. Simple. Here, we have three commanders, three quartermasters, three chains of supply. We have been working beside each other, not together.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Calatrava speaks truth. When problems arose, each Order blamed the others because no one had authority to solve them. We need a single commander under Your Majesty. Someone who can knock heads together when quartermasters squabble over spoiled meat.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of the camp water, Your Majesty. We have moved the latrine trenches and forbidden use of the contaminated stream. But the men are wary. Some have been drinking only wine for days. Clean water barrels from the city would help. A visible sign that the problem is solved.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Regarding the command structure; we need one subordinate commander under myself. And one quarter master. Lets not make a choice right now, but rather think about it for one day. I want the most experienced and capable commander and quarter master in command. We will meet back here tomorrow. Either you have chosen a commander and quarter master yourself from your own ranks or I will appoint someone on the spot. Either way, we will have one quarter master and one commander. I will make sure there is fresh water.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The tent falls silent. The three commanders stand frozen, processing what Juan has just done. He has not chosen between them—which would have created a winner and two resentful losers. He has not imposed an outsider—which would have united them in indignation. He has told them to solve it themselves, or have the decision taken from their hands. It is elegant. And uncomfortable.

exchanges.speaker: rodrigo_de_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is wise to give us time. Santiago will... confer with the other Orders.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Calatrava concurs. One day. We will present a unified recommendation. Or we will accept Your Majesty's judgment.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: I will arrange the fresh water barrels, Your Majesty. And dispatch riders to Tarragona within the hour. Is there anything else before we adjourn?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We all have our assignments, we meet back here tomorrow.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with his military commanders to address the expedition's crisis. After breaking up their feuding, he secures hospital care for sick men, arranges expanded food supplies through multiple Mediterranean ports, and forces the three Order commanders to choose unified leadership or have it imposed upon them by tomorrow.

roll.outcome: Strong success. Hospital welcomes the sick; physicians optimistic. María provides generously—roasted meats, good bread, Catalan delicacies. Camp conditions improve visibly. Men begin to believe.

encounters.recap: Juan personally oversees comprehensive improvements to the crusader camp. The Hospital de la Santa Creu accepts all sixty sick knights, María arranges a generous feast from palace stores, fresh water barrels arrive, and latrines are properly relocated. The camp transforms from a place of despair into one of renewed hope and purpose.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The nursery is warm, lit by a single candle. Catalina lies in her small bed, blankets pulled up to her chin, her dark hair spread across the pillow like spilled ink. Her eyes flutter open as Juan enters.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Papa smells funny.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Inés stifles a laugh from her corner, then curtsies and withdraws to give them privacy. When Juan asks about singing, Catalina nods solemnly.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I was singing to the horse. He was scared. The dark is scary for horses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches up, small fingers finding Juan's hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Sing, Papa. Sing the good one.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan sings. Catalina's eyes grow heavy. Her grip on his hand loosens. Her breathing slows, deepens. Somewhere in the middle of the lullaby, she slips away into dreams—perhaps of horses that jump very high, or ships with many sails, or crostatas shared with queens. When the song ends, she is asleep. The candle flickers. Beyond the window, Barcelona lies quiet under winter stars. Somewhere in the camp, seven hundred men sleep with full bellies. Somewhere in the hospital, sixty sick knights rest in clean beds. And here, in this small room, a princess sleeps with her wooden horse watching over her. Lucia appears in the doorway, silhouetted by the light from their chambers. She says nothing. She does not need to.

encounters.recap: After the day's crisis, Juan visits his daughter Catalina in the nursery. She asks him to sing a lullaby, and he does so until she falls asleep. Queen Lucia appears silently in the doorway, sharing this quiet family moment after the troubles of the day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The day has dawned grey and cold, but the camp is transformed. Men move with purpose. Cook fires burn cleanly. The new latrine trenches steam in the morning chill, properly distant from the water supply. Fresh bread is being distributed—María's generosity extending into a second day. Word has spread about the king who inspected latrines. About the Regent of Aragón who opened her stores. About the sick brothers now resting in the finest hospital in Catalunya. The men do not cheer as Juan passes. They do something better. They stand straighter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The command tent is the same as yesterday—cramped, utilitarian, the table still covered with manifests and maps. But the atmosphere has shifted. The three commanders are already present when Juan arrives. They stand together—not in their separate corners as before, but clustered near the table. They have been talking.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. We have... conferred. As Your Majesty commanded. It was not easy. Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara have proud traditions. None of us wished to kneel to another.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: But Your Majesty was clear. One commander. One quartermaster. Unity, or have the choice made for us.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: We have a proposal, Your Majesty. If you will hear it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets have it then.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Command should go to the man with the most experience leading combined forces. That is not me. Santiago has fought alone, gloriously—but this expedition requires coordination between Orders.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: At the siege of Antequera, I served as second to the Infante Ferdinand. Three Orders under one banner. I know how it is done—the politics, the rotations, the wounded pride that must be managed. I am not the youngest, nor do I command the largest contingent. But I have done this before.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: Alcántara supports Commander Mendoza for overall command. In exchange, the unified quartermaster position goes to our man—Sergeant Tomás de Palencia. He has served Alcántara's supply lines for eleven years. He predicted the spoiled meat. He warned about the camp placement. No one listened.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Santiago concurs. Mendoza commands. Alcántara supplies. I will serve as Mendoza's second. My men will follow his orders as they would follow mine.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: This is our proposal, Your Majesty. If it does not please you, we will accept whatever command structure you impose. But we believe this can work.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have chosen a commander and quartermaster from your ranks. I accept. Commander Mendoza, some men lack proper equipment. I expect every men to be fighting fit and properly equipped. Take measures to make it so. Quartermaster, how are we on the meat? When do we have enough for us to leave?

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I will conduct a full inspection today. Every man, every blade, every hauberk. What is lacking, we will procure. Barcelona has armorers. What cannot be bought, we will requisition from the Orders' reserves in the city. Alcántara's equipment requests will be filled first. They have waited longest.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_palencia
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I received the supply reports an hour ago. We have sixty-three barrels of salt meat in camp. The riders reached Tarragona yesterday evening. The salting houses there have stock—they can provide one hundred twenty barrels, ready for transport. At a premium. They know we are desperate. The barrels should arrive by March third. That gives us one hundred eighty-three total. Short of Your Majesty's target of two hundred fifty to three hundred. But I have also sent word to Tortosa—smaller market, but closer. If they can provide another forty to sixty barrels... March fifth, Your Majesty. Perhaps March fourth if the Tortosa shipment arrives early. We could sail with two hundred forty barrels—near the lower end of your requirement—and resupply in Rome as planned. Will this suffice, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This will be sufficient. This gives the men more time to recover as well. We plan to sail at march 5th. Anything else for now?

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: The sick, Your Majesty. Sixty men in the hospital. The physicians say most will recover—but perhaps not all by March fifth. Some may need another week. Perhaps two.

exchanges.speaker: commander_cervantes
exchanges.text: Do we leave them behind? Or delay further?

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_palencia
exchanges.text: We could sail with reduced numbers and arrange for recovered men to follow on later vessels. Merchant ships make the Rome passage regularly. It would cost, but... It is possible.

exchanges.speaker: commander_orozco
exchanges.text: The men who recover should have the choice. Some will want to follow, even if it means traveling alone. Others may... Not every man who survives fever survives it whole. Some may never fight again.

exchanges.speaker: commander_mendoza
exchanges.text: We will know more by March fifth. The physicians can tell us who is fit, who will recover, and who...

exchanges.speaker: ferran_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is also the matter of the fleet, Your Majesty. The ships have been waiting in harbor. I have sent word that we sail on the fifth, but the captains will want confirmation. And the flagship—the Princesa Catalina—should be inspected before departure. Will Your Majesty wish to address the men again before we sail? Now that they are fed and rested, the words might land differently.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will adress them again, but later when we are about to depart. I want to make sure no other issues crop up. I will inspect the fleet shortly. And will be at camp regularly from now on. The campain has begun.

encounters.recap: The three military order commanders present a unified proposal for command structure after private negotiations. Mendoza of Calatrava becomes overall commander, Palencia of Alcántara becomes quartermaster, and Cervantes of Santiago accepts second-in-command. Juan accepts their proposal, sets March 5th as the departure date, and commits to regular presence at camp as the campaign officially begins.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The journey from the palace to the harbor is short, but Catalina makes it feel like an expedition to distant lands. "The ship is called what?" Lucia smiles, adjusting Catalina on her hip as they descend toward the docks. "Princesa Catalina, my love. Named after you." Catalina's eyes grow very round. "A whole ship? With my name?" "A whole ship. The biggest one in the fleet." Catalina processes this information with the gravity it deserves. Her small brow furrows. "Does the ship know it has my name?" "I think the ship is very proud," Lucia says. "Good." Catalina nods firmly. "It should be. Catalina is a very good name."

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The harbor spreads before them—a forest of masts and rigging, the snap of canvas, the cries of gulls and dockworkers. The smell of tar and salt and fish hangs thick in the air. And there, riding at anchor in the outer harbor, is the Princesa Catalina. She is a carrack—three-masted, high-castled, her hull painted in the red and gold of Castile. The royal standard flies from her mainmast. She is not the largest ship ever built, but she is substantial—a vessel meant to carry a king across dangerous waters.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That one? The big one?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: That one.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mine?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Named after you, cariño. Not quite the same thing.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Mine.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. And the Princess herself. The ship has been waiting to meet its namesake.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The boat crosses the harbor in minutes, but for Catalina it might as well be a voyage to the edge of the world. She grips the gunwale with white-knuckled intensity, staring at everything—the oarsmen, the seabirds, the approaching bulk of "her" ship. "It's big," she whispers.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. Welcome to the Princesa Catalina. She completed sea trials in December. Stable in heavy swells. Handles better than any carrack I've commanded in thirty years.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cabin beyond is surprisingly spacious—paneled in dark wood, with windows of thick glass looking out over the stern. A bed built into the bulkhead, wide enough for two. Cushioned benches along the walls. A writing desk secured to the deck. Tapestries hang to soften the wood and muffle the creak of timber. It was designed for Isabel. She never saw it. Lucia steps inside, her hand trailing along the polished wood. Her expression is unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: This is mine?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: This is the queen's cabin, little one. For your mama.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia-mama. She can have it. It's nice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Sotomayor leads them through the ship with the pride of a man showing off his life's work. The king's cabin adjacent to the queen's chambers, smaller and more functional—a soldier's space. The great cabin below, spanning the width of the stern, where councils will be held and meals taken. A long table dominates the space, bolted to the deck.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Where are the cannons?

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Twelve bombards. Six to each side. Not the heaviest—we sacrificed weight for speed and stability—but enough to discourage pirates and punish any galley foolish enough to close with us. She's not a warship. Not built to stand in a battle line. But she can fight if she must, and outrun what she cannot fight.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But I want to see it boom.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Perhaps when we are at sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: In the hold, the smell changes—bilge water, tar, the mustiness of stored provisions. "Stores for three months if we must," Sotomayor explains. "Water barrels here, salt meat, biscuit, dried fish. Wine. Oil. Everything a crew of eighty needs to cross any sea."

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: It smells funny.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: All ships smell funny, little one. You get used to it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The view from the bow is extraordinary. The harbor spreads before them, Barcelona's spires rising beyond. The sea stretches to the horizon, grey-green and endless. Catalina grips the rail, the wind whipping her dark hair.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Where is Constanti-popple?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Constantinople. Far away, cariño. Many days sailing. Past Rome, past Naples, past many islands.

exchanges.speaker: diego_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Eighty souls, Your Majesty. Sailors, marines, gunners, officers. Every man knows his duty. Every man has sailed with me before. She is ready, Your Majesty. The Princesa Catalina will carry you wherever you need to go.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: It is a good ship.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Can we sail now?

encounters.recap: Juan takes Lucia and Catalina to inspect the flagship Princesa Catalina in Barcelona harbor. The young princess is delighted that the great carrack bears her name, while Captain Sotomayor gives them a comprehensive tour of the vessel's royal cabins, gun deck, holds, and fighting platforms. The ship is well-built and ready for the coming voyage to Constantinople, though the queen's cabin—originally designed for Isabel—carries poignant reminders of the past.
